Award.AwardTitle: Integrative program to sustain and strengthen colloidal and interfacial science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (CAI-STEM) capabilities

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1351543
Alcantar

The PI proposes a collaborative workshop to establish a strong scientific dialogue among researchers involved in colloids, interfacial science, and separation technology. The workshop will be held in Cancun, Mexico in May 2014.

The goal of the workshop is to enhance innovation, design, and biomedical applications of colloids, interfaces, and separation systems that could revolutionize research and manufacturing practices in the U.S. In this integrative communications program, it is propose to mix researchers who have dedicated their lives to investigations and discoveries in colloids, interfacial science, and separations with mid-term and young scientists in STEM disciplines to promote their interaction. The objective is to catalyze collaborations that lead to high impact invention, enterprise, and medical research.

A 5 - 8 day meeting is proposed. It is expect that national and international experts in experimental and theoretical CAI and STEM who would not normally meet to exchange ideas will convene, with the goal of interdisciplinary advances that will benefit all investigators.

The organizing committee will develop a website for consolidating registration and disseminating learning and logistic information about the workshop. The PI anticipates having publishing the workshop results in two special issues of Langmuir and the Journal of Colloids and Surfaces. The editors of both journals have expressed interest.

This workshop will be co-funded by the Office of Naval Research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The mission of this collaborative effort was to establish a strong scientific dialogue among researchers involved in the science and technology of surface forces, colloids, interfacial phenomena, and separations. The concept was to jump-start and enhance innovation, design, and biomedical applications of colloids, interfaces, and separation systems that could revolutionize research and manufacturing practices of interest to the US. In this integrative communications program, we were able to mix top-notch researchers who have dedicated their lives to investigations and discoveries in the role of surface forces in colloidal and interfacial science and technology with mid-term and young scientists in science and engineering disciplines to promote their interaction. This mixing enabled the development of collaborations that lead to high impact in invention, enterprise, and medical research. A 6 day meeting took place in Cancun Mexico with a heavy presence from (Consejo National de Ciencia y Technologia in Mexico) CONACyT-funded researchers, which have continued collaborating with the organizers. Moreover, we gathered national and international experts in experimental and theoretical surface forces and interfacial phenomena who would not normally meet to exchange ideas will convene, with the goal of interdisciplinary advances that benefited the science and technology related to colloidal systems and separations.   

 

The audience of the conference included scientists who have worked in surface forces and who extended their basic understanding of the role of colloids, interfacial phenomena, and separation systems in natural processes.  The explosion of ideas in colloidal and interfacial (CAI) science has led to innovation in the industries of cosmetics, paints and coatings, adhesives, pharmaceuticals, food, green processing, composites, solvents, oil and perfume extractions, absorptive materials, among the most important. CAI also has been instrumental in the creation of new materials and in discoveries in the properties of materials. For example, the transition of solid metal to liquid by inducing a cohesive pressure has had a tremendous impact on nanofabrication technology.
